Advanced Vocabulary - Page 12

Advanced

Advanced Vocabulary - Page 12

Congratulations! You've completed all 144 advanced vocabulary words. These sophisticated terms will significantly enhance your ability to communicate with precision, eloquence, and intellectual depth in formal academic and professional contexts.

Navigation

This is the final page (12 of 12). Use the navigation below to review previous pages or return to the vocabulary overview.

Word List

Prescient

/ˈpresiənt/

adjective

Having or showing knowledge of events before they take place.

"Her prescient warnings about the market crash proved accurate."

Synonyms: prophetic, foresighted, clairvoyant

Category: Foresight

Pretentious

/prɪˈtenʃəs/

adjective

Attempting to impress by affecting greater importance, talent, culture, etc., than is actually possessed.

"The pretentious art critic used unnecessarily complex language."

Synonyms: pompous, affected, ostentatious

Category: Attitude

Procrastinate

/proʊˈkræstəneɪt/

verb

Delay or postpone action; put off doing something.

"Students often procrastinate when faced with difficult assignments."

Synonyms: delay, postpone, defer

Category: Time Management

Profligate

/ˈprɑːflɪɡət/

adjective, noun

Recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources.

"His profligate spending habits led to financial ruin."

Synonyms: wasteful, extravagant, spendthrift

Category: Spending

Propitious

/prəˈpɪʃəs/

adjective

Giving or indicating a good chance of success; favorable.

"The sunny weather was propitious for their outdoor wedding."

Synonyms: favorable, auspicious, promising

Category: Fortune

Quintessential

/ˌkwɪntəˈsenʃəl/

adjective

Representing the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class.

"He was the quintessential gentleman, always polite and considerate."

Synonyms: typical, archetypal, perfect

Category: Perfection

Recalcitrant

/rɪˈkælsɪtrənt/

adjective

Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline.

"The recalcitrant student refused to follow classroom rules."

Synonyms: stubborn, defiant, unruly

Category: Behavior

Reclusive

/rɪˈklusɪv/

adjective

Avoiding the company of other people; solitary.

"The reclusive author rarely gave interviews or public appearances."

Synonyms: solitary, hermit-like, withdrawn

Category: Social Behavior

Sagacious

/səˈɡeɪʃəs/

adjective

Having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgment; wise.

"The sagacious advisor helped navigate the complex negotiations."

Synonyms: wise, perceptive, astute

Category: Wisdom

Sanguine

/ˈsæŋɡwɪn/

adjective

Optimistic or positive, especially in an apparently bad or difficult situation.

"Despite the setbacks, she remained sanguine about the project's success."

Synonyms: optimistic, hopeful, confident

Category: Attitude

Ubiquitous

/juˈbɪkwətəs/

adjective

Present, appearing, or found everywhere.

"Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society."

Synonyms: omnipresent, pervasive, widespread

Category: Presence

Zealous

/ˈzeləs/

adjective

Having or showing great energy or enthusiasm in pursuit of a cause or objective.

"The zealous activist campaigned tirelessly for environmental protection."

Synonyms: enthusiastic, passionate, fervent

Category: Enthusiasm
